results.title: Bourgeois dictionaries (Private Hungary 7)
results.brief_description:
Forgacs recontextualizes archival home movies and film journals from the 1930s through to the 1950s, taking small moments, individual shots or whole sequences from a variety of sources and editing them together into a mosaic of middle class Hungarian life.

The soundtrack layers political radio broadcasts of the times over the ambient music of Tibor Szemzo, creating a sense of expectancy, of fate. The images however are resolutely concerned with the everyday, the personal, the pleasurable. Tantalising glimpses of cafe society, fur coats, cigars, flirtations, erotic encounters and picnics are interspersed with moments that mark turning points in family life; a father laid in state, poppy seed loaves being baked as a son leaves for the front, a daughter’s first communion.

The 2nd world war is referred to in an incidental way; planes flying over head intercut with the 1944 figure skating championships or a little cat being petted in the bombed out ruins of a building. A catalogue of daily life at once nostalgic and familiar.

results.title: Brass
results.creator_credit: Sidney A. Franklin, Harry Rapf and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Philip Baldwin (Monte Blue) is the son of a prosperous fruit-farmer. His marriage to Rosemary, daughter of his father’s best friend has been planned since they were children, but when gold-digging city girl Marjorie (Marie Prevost) finds work during the summer vacation at the ranch, she seduces Philip into marriage. Domestic problems, city living and friction with his mother-in-law contribute to Marjorie divorcing Philip and abandoning their son. Philip then discovers true love with Mrs Grotenberg (Irene Rich) the widow who boards with the family and cares for the child. Cast also includes Harry Meyers, Frank Keenan and Harvey Clark. Based on the novel by Charles G. Norris.

results.title: Branchline railway
results.brief_description: Michael Palin, confessed train buff, introduces unique footage from the BBC archive: Branchline Railway and two historic newsreel sequences - a splendid requiem for the steam railway. “Branchline Railway”: the late Sir John Betjeman presents this little known film which perfectly captures the atmosphere of a 24 mile stretch of the now vanished Somerset and Dorset railway. It celebrates a working, living railway, complete with dirty locomotives, clean stations decked with flowers, and austere gas-lit waiting rooms. It all belongs to a vanished age but the film remains to delight and inform (broadcast 1963). “Britannia under her own steam” looks at the naming of the first magnificent Class 7 4-6-2 Standard locomotives ‘Britannia’ (broadcast 1951). “Atlantic Coast Express” is a footplate journey on Merchant Navy Class No. 35016 ‘Elder Fyffe’ as it heads the ‘Atlantic Coast Express’ (broadcast 1960).

results.title: Brain story. Eps. 04-06
results.creator_credit: Zoe Heron, Thecla Schreuders, Sam Roberts and BBC
results.brief_description: Brain Story is a series of six programs exploring the latest research on brain function. Professor Susan Greenfield CBE, presenter of the series, uses current scientific technology to help answer a number of philosophical questions about who we are as people and what makes you ‘you’ and the brain’s role in this. Episode 4: “First amongst equals” investigates why humans use their brains beyond survival instincts. The frontal lobes in our brain controls our ability to plan and make goals. An extensive study of chimpanzees and their language ability is used to illustrate the difference between animal and human brain function and why we as humans seek to excel beyond survival. Episode 5: “Growing the mind” explores how memory is developed throughout our lives, the physical conditions to facilitate this in the brain and how beyond ‘semantic memory’ our memory defines us as individuals. Episode 6: “The Final mystery” explores vividly how the brain creates the conscious experience of being you. Greenfield establishes how our daily actions are the result of slowly emerging sub-conscious processes in the brain. (Episode 6 features The Jim Rose Circus).

results.title: Brain sex. Episode 3
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Harris, Ann Moir, Cheryl Knapp, Discovery Channel, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Primetime Television, Quality Time TV and Primedia Productions
results.brief_description: The final program in this series looks primarily at the sexual behaviour of men and women, how it differs, and each sex’s perceptions of the opposite sex’s motivation. It also looks at more differences between the female and male brains, particularly in relation to aging, and relationships with the opposite sex.

results.title: Bound [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Lana Wachowski, Lilly Wachowski, Stuart Boros, Andrew Lazar and De Laurentiis Entertainment Group
results.brief_description: A stylish and sexy noir thriller directed by the Wachowski Brothers. Corky (Gina Gershon) has just finished a stint in the slammer, and has been hired to renovate the apartment next door to Caeser (Joe Pantoliano), and his vampish girlfriend, Violet (Jennifer Tilly). Violet pursues Corky and they have an affair, which leads to them plotting to steal two million dollars of stashed Mafia money currently in Caeser’s custody. Can they pull off this daring theft, or will an unexpected twist in their otherwise flawless plan lead to their downfall?

results.title: Brain sex. Episode 2
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Harris, Ann Moir, Discovery Channel, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Primetime Television, Quality Time TV and Primedia Productions
results.brief_description: This program looks at differences between the two genders, both real and perceived, and the new discoveries by researchers into the brain, which suggest that these differences are due to physical differences in the male and female brain. How much of our behaviour is predetermined and how much can be learnt or modified should perhaps be reassessed in the light of these discoveries, and new attitudes to difference and equality formed.

results.title: Boudu Sauve des Eaux = Boudu Saved from Drowning
results.creator_credit: Jean Renoir, Michel Simon and Jean Gehret
results.brief_description:
Boudu, a rambling tramp, is taken into the middle-class household of a Parisian book seller after being rescued from the Seine. Boudu shows scant regard for bourgeois decorum. The humour is gently satirical and subversive rather than cutting, but is far from the original play’s affirmation of middle-class culture. Renoir’s use of long takes, camera movement, depth of field in loosely framed compositions with the continuous suggestion of a world beyond the frame, was the antithesis of the then developing Hollywood style of tight compositions and reverse angle cutting. Re-made as ‘Down and out in Beverly Hills’ by Paul Mazursky (1986). Further reading: Richard Boston. ‘Boudu saved from drowning’. London: BFI Publishing, 1994.

Credits: Producer, Jean Gehret, Michel Simon ; director, Jean Renoir ; writers, Jean Renoir, Robert Valentin ; photography, Marcel Lucien, George Asselin ; music, Raphael, Johann Strauss ; editor, Marguerite Houlle-Renoir, Suzanne de Troeye ; assistan
Cast: Michel Simon, Charles Granval, Marcelle Haina, Severine Lerczynska, Max Dalban, Jean Gehret, Jean Daste, Jacques Becker, Jane Pierson.

results.title: Brain sex. Episode 1
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Harris, Discovery Channel, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Primetime Television, Quality Time TV and Primedia Productions
results.brief_description: Our chromosomes are decided at conception, and shortly thereafter hormones start to play their part in determining sex. This program investigates the role that hormones play in determining sex and sexual characteristics, including behaviour patterns. Can hormones change brain structure? Does the brain determine gender related characteristics? The program looks at studies of children who suffer from Turner’s syndrome and CAH syndrome as we attempt to unravel the roles of nature and nurture in patterns of behaviour.
